org.eng.util

Class ComponentProperties

  • java.lang.Object
    • org.eng.util.ComponentProperties
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    AISPProperties, ENGProperties, IOTPlatformProperties

    public class ComponentProperties
extends Object
    Provides a search space for a set of properties identified by a component name. The component name is used to define the names of environment and system variables where the properties file is searched for. The getPropertyURL() is the method that is responsible for the search order, which is defined as follows for an instance with name 'foo':
    1. a file name specified by the environment variable with name FOO_PROPERTIES_FILE
    2. a file name specified by the system property foo.properties.file
    3. a foo.properties file in the current directory.
    4. the path composed with the value of the FOO_HOME environment variable as follows:
      • $FOO_HOME/foo.properties
      • $FOO_HOME/lib/foo.properties
    5. foo.properties as a resource of the instance's ClassLoader.
    When requesting property values, properties are first searched for in the Java System properties, and if not found there, then the properties file specified above is used. This allows the associated component properties file to define the defaults, but have them overridden on the command line via -Dproperty=value syntax.
    Author:
    dawood

    • Constructor Detail

      • ComponentProperties

        public ComponentProperties(String componentName)
        Create a component with the given name. Name should not contain spaces or special characters other than '-', which will be replaced with '_' in the name of the HOME environment variable name.
        Parameters:
        componentName - case-insensitive name of the component.

        public String getComponentName()
        Name of component.
        Returns:
        never null, always lower case.

      • getProperty

        public String getProperty(Class clazz,
                          String name)
        Get the property whose name is built from the class name and the given suffix. The property name is created by concatenating the full dotted name of the class, another dot, and the given name. The String value for that system property as returned by System.getProperty(String) is returned.
        Parameters:
        clazz -
        name -
        Returns:
        the value of the property

      • getProperty

        public int getProperty(Class clazz,
                       String name,
                       int dflt)
        Get the integer value of system or property and if not found use the given default. The property name is derived using the same mechanism as #getSystemProperty(Class, String). We first check the system properties and then search properties.
        Parameters:
        clazz -
        name -
        dflt -
        Returns:

        public String getHomeEnvVarName()

        Returns:

        Returns:

      • getHomePath

        public String getHomePath()
        Get the name of the directory considered to be the home for this component. We search first the environment variable then the system property.
        Returns:
        null if not specified.

      • getPropertyFileDir

        public File getPropertyFileDir()
        Get the directory where the properties file is being read from and is known to exist.
        Returns:
        null if we can't find a directory containing the properties file.

      • getPropertyFile

        public File getPropertyFile()
        Deprecated. in favor of getPropertyURL()
        Get the File object that references this component's properties file according the search strategy defined by this class (see above).
        Returns:
        never null

      • getPropertyFilePath

        public String getPropertyFilePath()
        Deprecated. in favor of getPropertyURL()
        Get the full path to the properties file that will be used to resolved property look ups.
        Returns:

      • getPropertyURL

        public URL getPropertyURL()
        Get a URL to the properties file. First we search the file system according the class documentation, and if not found, then we use ClassLoader.getResource(String).
        Returns:
        a URL or null if not found.

      • getProperty

        public String getProperty(String propertyName)
        Get the value of the given property (ala java.util.Properties) from the properties file returned by getPropertyURL().
        Parameters:
        propertyName -
        Returns:
        null if the named property is not found.

      • getProperty

        public int getProperty(String propertyName,
                       int dflt)
        Get the value of the given property (ala java.util.Properties) from the properties file returned by getPropertyURL() and if it doesn't exist, return the given default value. If the property value can not be parsed to an int, then it a message is logged and the default is used.
        Parameters:
        propertyName -
        dflt - value to return if the property does not exist.
        Returns:
        dflt if the named property is not found, otherwise the property value as in integer.

      • getProperty

        public boolean getProperty(String propertyName,
                           boolean dflt)
        Get the value of the given property (ala java.util.Properties) from the properties file returned by getPropertyURL() and if it doesn't exist, return the given default value. If the property value can not be parsed to a boolean, then it a message is logged and the default is used.
        Parameters:
        propertyName -
        dflt - value to return if the property does not exist.
        Returns:
        dflt if the named property is not found, otherwise the property value as in boolean.

      • changeProperty

        public void changeProperty(String propertyName,
                           String value,
                           boolean persist)
        Replace the value of the given property (ala java.util.Properties) from the properties File. This only works when the properties are coming from a writable file (and not a URL as in getPropertyURL().
        Parameters:
        propertyName -
        value -
        persist - if true, then persist the change to the underlying property file.

      • getProperty

        public String getProperty(String propertyName,
                          String dflt)
        Look in the system properties for the named property and if doesn't exist then get it out of the component properties file identified by getPropertyURL(). If it doesn't exist in either, then returnt the given default value.
        Parameters:
        propertyName -
        dflt - value to return if the property does not exist.
        Returns:
        dflt if the named property is not found, otherwise the property value.

      • reload

        public void reload()
        Reload the properties from the properties file.

      • setProperties

        public void setProperties(Properties props,
                          ComponentLogger logger)
        Install the given properties as the properties to use for this component. The properties are not persisted to the file system by this call.
        Parameters:
        props -
        logger - optional logger that is using these properties and is to be notified of the change.

      • setPropertyFilePath

        public void setPropertyFilePath(String propFile,
                                ComponentLogger logger)
        Set the location and name of the properties file overriding other environment and properties mechanisms of setting the location. To revert to those mechanisms, set the location to 'null'. Whenever this is set, the previously loaded properties (if any) are discarded, so that the next call to getProperty(String) will cause a new set or properties to be loaded.
        Parameters:
        propFile - filename or null.
        logger - optional logger that is using these properties and is to be notified of the change.

      • getProperties

        public Properties getProperties()
        Returns:
        the componentProperties
